title: Works excellent, esp used with XSDL android xserver. The only thing i would fix is to allow setup directly on ext3/4 partitions if the script finds itself on one, no upside to installing on a loopback in that case. I am using in on Android-x86 and it works flawlessly.
comment: If the mouse pointer loses sync, pull down an Android menu item and select it. On 4.4+ it will then go full screen and sync the pointer. Also, if you run /data/media/dev/mk-debian script manually, jessie works far better than anything else compatibility wise, save for andromize. amd64 works too if you have an x86-64 kernel, but you have to set the option when running the script. Also: Is there a wiki where we can ask questions/pose solutions for Debian-kit?

title: Well made

title: Already failed at first hurdle
comment: Where to begin? The symlink for the command deb was never created, trying to install the andromizer-lxde, it created a huge spawn of problems, ones which prevented a rooted system permission to fix. Lastly, when trying to uninstall Debian, I was unable to perform any deb arguments, instead, I was returned to the deb shell, which forced me to reboot my system, just to remove Debian. Debian is an amazing OS, but this app is not worth the effort.

title: Samsung Galaxy Note 4
comment: Does not recognize root access. I have rooted my phone but when I tried to install it it says that my phone is not rooted.

title: Works on Archos 70B Titanium
comment: Works well on this tablet with no lag. Everything runs smoothly although the install did take a long time (possibly just my internet connection).  Here are the device details: Operating system: Android 4.1 Jelly Bean Display: 7" capacitive multitouch screen - IPS technology - 1280X800 CPU: Dual-Core ARM Cortex A9 @ 1.6GHz Graphics: Quad-Core Mali-400 GPU RAM: 1GB DDR3 Extra features: Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, micro sd slot (up to 32GB), front camera, micro USB host, micro HDMI output. You can add this to your tested-devices list. Thanks

Very cool thing to have "almost real" Debian within my Android. Android has SSH access to Debian, and Debian has (someway limited) access to Android file system. Installed git and nodejs, no need for external server!

title: The best app so far
comment: Does what it promises. You have to follow the instructions very carefully, it's easy to break the installation. At the bottom it says it's not perfect, I'm trying to get audio working at the moment.

title: S4 unsupported CPU
comment: I already have super-su. Installed busy box and even set selinux to passive before install..... it unpacked fine but never prompted the install..... so I look in /data/local/deb and ran the install. It says "unsupported CPU/architecture"..... The developer did a decent job you guys. At least he included a message that CPU is not supported rather than the install blasting away and ffffffing everything up.

title: It's wonderful having a full linux intermingled with android.. desktop through RDP is better than vnc. some problems
comment: Using Debian Jesse... copying to external micro-sd card from within debian reboots on nook stock root (ICS)... You should give an option for larger loop-file-systems for people who have exfat (large file support).  I expanded the disk by hand.

title: Truly awesome.
comment: This puts back all the stuff which should have been included in the basic android, and then some. If you are a *nix geek, you *need* this.  The ability to apt-get a metric ton of packages onto retired devices is simply amazing.

title: Unbelievable
comment: This is amazing! The integration with android is perfect. In effect it gives me a perfect openssh to my android without some half baked app. Also setup my SQL apache and php so I can develop my sites anywhere! I have no interest in the GUI aspect, it's perfect as a debian server.    I chose the testing Debian I am running a blue dash 5.0 with android 4.2 rooted

title: Works great !!
comment: I have an Atrix 2 with lapdock and i followed the instructions and.worked very good, wish I could install ubuntu with unity. Great job !x!

title: Beautiful
comment: It installed and worked beautifully in Nexus 7 16Gb. I had to set LANG=en_US. UTF-8 in the 'deb' script in order to use utf accented characters. I also installed bVNC free viewer and the External Keyboard Helper Pro to use the linux windows system with a bluetooth keyboard being able to input accented and control characters (I lost patience with RDP) .  Now I can work in the tablet using the same system and tools as in my desktop and laptop. Thanks! 2014-06-01 Now I have debian jessie installed on an external microSD and running on an Asus Transformer TF300T in parallel with Android, with which it can share files.

title: Working well
comment: You may need to set SELINUX mode permissive in order to use Debian properly. Otherwise groupadd/useradd not working.

title: Better than the others.
comment: Tried just about all the others and they fail on the first or second step.  Every one.  I suspect this is because they don't keep up with changes to Android but who knows / cares.  This is the only one that works on 4.3 that I've found.  LXDE is very quick with the suggested viewer.

title: DNS Issue Fixed
comment: This is a really wonderful app, but renew your DNS or something. I'm getting a 504 Gateway error whenever I try to access the website.. :( fix please and Ill give the rating this app deserves. EDIT: Fixed. Not sure if it was ur issue or server/nameserver. But its fixed so I can use the PPA repos. Thanks this is amazing. Ironically had to use an alternative Shar file. 1.6. By devorak or something. Should implement it in your repos.

title: Very good
comment: Super-chroot don't use image's space well well well you are all my need for a computer

title: Awesome!
comment: As a newbie for linux, I tried getting debian on my tablet to use it like a raspberry pi like device. I have tried other alternatives but alot couldnt start because of issues with loops and stuff like that. I have ran into some problems but have managed to fix them, like the root password.  To fix root:  You can actually change the root password by going into commandbot  and typing: [Debian] su (enter) passwd root (enter), and then it will prompt you to setup a new password for root. this should work, it worked for me. Great App anyway!

title: Great and Working
comment: Great app but you have to follow every step, in order, no skipping. The hardest part is that it is all manual. But I love it :)

title: Very useful, nicely scripted
comment: This kit does what it says, and does it well. Installing on an SGH-I317M Galaxy Note II, using (full disclosure) Eric Doviak's slightly modified version to install Wheezy, all went well. Debian on a phablet, with a folding Bluetooth keyboard, and it's a new definition for 'ultraportable'. Very nice to have the real Linux toolchains available.
Thanks is excellent.

title: Excellent!
comment: Very conviniant to use.

title: BEST Debian Linux App ever !! Not a chroot one. Native Android fs.
comment: Deffo a GREAT app but RTFM first. Installed on a TF300T, not with ConnectBot but the excellent Terminal Emulator. All went great with no hassles.  PS: one question: in RDP/lxde what is the default root password if I open a root terminal? I haven't set one, so far.

title: Wonderful
comment: I've been running this for months without issue. I remember feeling a little lost when I got started (being a debian/ubuntu noob), but have not looked back at all. Thanks!

title: Works great
comment: Installed on HTC Nexus One, no problem. Must read carefully and understand the instructions! Takes a little time investment.   After getting it working on my GN1 (with only 384MB RAM), I was able to simply copy the Debian disk image and installation scripts over to my Galaxy Note 10.1 tablet, and the whole Debian environment just transferred over with no problem, even login accounts and passwords - I didn't need to re-download and install all the Debian packages, setup etc, again. Awesomeness :-)

title: Poor documentation - Low usability
comment: One has to get serious, the more I look into the usability of this app the worse it gets. Usability is the level of consideration towards the user, the average user that is and not a specialist. The problem is it's lack of documentation. And if there is some guide it jumps from layman to expert level hence and back that makes you wonder who the developer is really addressing. There's no way to learn anything from it, absolutely nothing. Despite the number of times I suggested a more didactic way of documenting this app the developer seems to ignore it. At least from here...Google Play.  If you follow EXACTLY what's on the video clip you may get lucky but once something stops the show you'd better email the developer. Meanwhile get your finger ready above the video pause since things go VERY FAST.  And once you succeeded and exited and want to re-enter and play with debian again the next day YOU'RE STUCK because there's absolutely nothing to help you re-enter the debian orbit. So it's an app for a (pretentious) elite. Sad.

title: Amazing
comment: Finally a quick way to get a debian shell on Android without chroot. Great job guys.

title: Works on Xperia J (ST26i) 11.2.A.0.31
comment: Works on stock ROM.  This app uses symlinks and bind-mount instead of chroot.

title: It is really working
comment: I have succesfully installed debian in my galaxy y and having fun
Great, straightforward setup with excellent documentation.

title: Debian side-by-side with Android
comment: Unlike other installers, Sven-Ola's Debian Kit does not run Debian in a chroot environment. It runs Debian natively, so that you can access your device's internal and external storage. In other words, Debian Kit enables you to seamless share files between Debian and Android. Connect a Bluetooth keyboard and your telephone becomes a desktop computer. This project is amazing.

title: The best Linux for Android - but no longer supported?
comment: Outstanding in every respect -- both a simple app to run Debian easily and, as it indicates, a toolkit to build more complex versions.  The next best thing to running native Linux on your Android device!

title: Good stuff
comment: Works very well on my i9100 (Galaxy S2). And for me is more usable than other Linux options i have tried.  Thankyou developer.

title: Works perfectly on my stock (rooted) Nexus 4
comment: I wanted to find a more "up to date" software stack than my old optware tree, but retain the ability to run  "side by side" with Android, instead of in a chroot. This app is perfect for that need. I have Ubuntu 12.04 apps co-existing happily with the rest of the Android filesystem.

title: Awesomeness
comment: Finally have native Linux installed on a phone and it is truly amazing. By the way, the app Terminal IDE is IMO the best shell to use for this and it has an amazing full keyboard installed. It takes seventy MB of internal memory but honestly if you're considering debian kit chances are you can spare the memory.

title: not bad at all
comment: not bad at-all, only real issue is that it needs to be able to make larger image files and have the option to do so, I ran out of space with 2gb pretty quickly and am currently copying over to an 8gb image. I intend to buy an additional sdcard to put it on, my device can have multiple sdcards (another option needed), and may do with with a partition as opposed to a file and make some simple mods to the startup scripts. apart from the works nicely.   also ubuntu precise doesn't have mesa binaries for arm, and I'm sure that mesa is the software solution for opengl &co. this is an issue for anything that uses opengl for drawing, which is quite a few things. would be nice to see binaries for mesa  take that back, I did an apt-get update then the packages for mesa where available, so the older packages must have been removed from the repository

title: Very Good
comment: An excellent kit, everything working on my Note2. If you can't connect your 'remote' desktop try Jump or Pocket Cloud clients and enable automatic login (put uid and password in before logging in). Only problem is even on the huge screen that my phone has, its still not really big enough for LXDE. Command line is quite handy though.

title: bad links
comment: The bootdeb file is not where step 1 hyperlink sends you to. Thus, cannot get passed step 1. I guess the creator let his file hosting subscription expire. Amature.

title: Droid 3
comment: Seems to work so far. Having problems getting root privs so I can open Synaptic, but I am fairly inexperienced with Linux.  This is the only app out of a few on the Market which I could get to work on this phone. Thanks!

title: Great stuff! But, having problems with apache
comment: This is great. Turns my transformer prime into a small desktop computer. However, when trying to install a Apache2 server (for local use only, to try out some stuff) the server doesn't start. I've read from the reviews somebody made it work. Is there something particular?

title: fast and easy
comment: went for the "0s" option for now and am quite happy to get various linux commands along side my android UI. It is nice to be able to apt-get whatever you are missing. I am not really tempted to go for X, chroot or dualboot - so this is a perfect fit so far. Thanks a lot!

title: Excellent but...
comment: Everything works except I found a mistake: I have 776mb of ram not 776gb of ram.

title: Great tool
comment: Love it, I was able to get squeeze up and running on my Motorola Bionic in just a couple hours using the app. Gui works smooth from the phone and via RDP on my Ubuntu laptop or windows desktop. Flawless victory!   Ryan  Moto Bionic Android ICS 4.04

title: Debian on your Android! Just in few steps!
comment: Really nice to have (almost) native Debian environment on Android Device. The text mode works flawlessly on the phone itself or remotely for me. LXDE is accessible only via Remmina RDC on PC or RDC from Xtralogic on phone. There must be some incompatibility of tightvnc/xrdp with current Remote RDP or 2X Client. I rate it 5 stars!

title: Full Linux
comment: Debian runs great on my galaxy s. This app is a great advertisement for the installation processes.

title: Poor documentation
comment: If your new to Linux forget about it. Installation is well documented and easy to follow but nothing about what to do after. Don't know what to do now.....

title: Awsome on ZTE BLADE
comment: It's just great. I loved the rtfm video, it made the installation process was easy. I installed apache2 just for fun, and it runs smoothly.

title: Excellent!
comment: I dont really care if this is the best out there, but the way that there videos and instructions to guide you from nothing to a running linux is what matters. It also checks your system before you even start, so you dont end up with nothing after a long set up. I also love it that this is free! Keep it up and I hope you add more OS support. Thank you sir.

title: Works great on note 2
comment: Unable to connect via xrdp but I can connect with running tightvncserver manually but only as root. Otherwise everything works great. I am using ubuntu precise and it's reasonably fast on the note 2.

title: good
comment: tried them all this is the best can add backtrack

title: Jolly good!
comment: OK for a Debian you need 127.0.1.1 VS 127.0.0.1. But it works! The video is way to fast so I have not successfully installed Ubuntu. Why no unity option just lxde? Unity is made for notebooks and tablets?

title: Works great on ASUS TF700
comment: This is the only debian chroot that worked for me. I have installed it with Ubuntu 10.04 w/ LXDE and later replaced the desktop to XFCE because of some missing features in LXDE. The native resolution on the TF700 is very high so when connecting with the RDP, everything is too small. To overcome the size issue I have made many configuration changes and using it with a lower resolution so it looks OK but not excellent - not related to this chroot, simply mentioning for future reference.  3 missing bits from making it 5 stars: 1) You can't set the image file size past 2GB, which is simply not enough for my needs... 2) Only the old Debian and Ubuntu releases worked for me. As a "bleeding edge" user I find it lacking.

title: Debian in my pocket, life is good!
comment: Worked well on my Incredible 2 running Kangdemnation V0.4 7/22/2012 (Unofficial AOKP).  Had a few issues with connectbot getting disconnected repeatedly during the install that resulted in me having to go through the manual install.  But that doesn't seem to be at all related to the Debian Kit as I get those frequent random disconnects all the time.   Installing on my rooted nook with a AOKP ROM there and having the same disconnect issues and haven't had time to finish the install manually.  Now I've got an excuse to pick up a bluetooth keyboard.  Only problem I've experienced is that while trying to run Chromium I'm getting some permission errors and the load on my phone was high enough that I never got an answer screen when an incoming call came in.  But I was still able to place a call while also interacting with the phone desktop through RDP from my real desktop so it was probably just bad timing getting a call right when I was pushing the poor little phone hard.

title: Made Debian easy
comment: Installed Debian easily if you read the manual, THE WHOLE THING.  It answers all the questions you should have. I didn't use RDP though, I used the lxde instructions on their website for Android instead using tightVNC.  I had some issues which were solved by restarting my phone.  This only happened during install.  The system would be read as "read only" and I'm not entirely sure why.  If you get these, restart your phone and try again.  Working great on my Samsung Galaxy S3 with the HDMI adapter.  Update: Works great on my Nexus 7 too.

title: fantastic work
comment: update:  toshiba thrive AT100 ... with ICS and squeeze... in external sdcard completely stable     thanks

title: Brilliant!  Workaround found for Android VPN
comment: This is just what I've been waiting for.  The "andromize" package seamlessly integrates Debian's networking with Android's, and also fixes Debian's UIDs and GIDs so they won't clash with Android.  Just found today that adding "CUSTOM_ROM=true" to the "deb" wrapper script (just prepending it to the "exec" line is enough) fixes the conflict with Android's VPN functionality (ASUS TF300T, stock ICS ROM).  Perhaps CUSTOM_ROM needs to be default?  Now, if only 2X Remote Desktop worked with xrdp (or supported VNC directly), then all my problems would be solved...
Sweet and simple.  Tiny little Linux with openssh-server now running on my tablet.  Works as advertised.

title: Great!
comment: Just what I wanted. Keep up the good work!

title: Great - Debian in my tablet!
comment: TF201 user directory /sdcard is 64GB and formatted as EXT4 , so to get 7GB image I had to run mk-debian by hand, but this was not a trouble. I recommend using the Remote RDP app, as suggested by author of Debian Kit, I first tried 2x app with no avail. If you download the kernel sources for your system from Asus support web page and get running kernel configuration from /proc/config.gz , you can compile modules for your android. The RAM size could pose the problem, compilation may consume more memory than available, and the compiler will be force closed. I used swap file created inside /sdcard. Eg. it is possible to compile isofs.ko, to read optical media with the tablet :) Also CUPS is fully functional, providing free printing from your Android with either 'lpr file' or from X window environment. One small problem though - the Android builtin VPN will not connect if the kit links/bind mounts are effective.

title: Works great on my warp
comment: Easy to follow instructions, and works great on the zte warp

title: Working, but with problem
comment: The lack of documentation with this sucks, it doesn't address many issues, such as the one I'm having. The system mounts as read only.  I'm going through a reinstallation, which is slow and time consuming even for a dual 1.2GHz (OC'd from 1GHz).  Instead of using ConnectBot, I'm using an SSH server on my phone and just accessing the command line that way.  It's working the same so far, but I need to find how to fix this issue of read only mounting. That makes this a little useless if it's read only.  I'm giving up on this, going to try another, but I can say I got it working up to the point that 1.4 is mounting a read only file system.

title: Works great...
comment: ...on rooted LG Mytouch Q (LGC800). GUI works slow on my cell, so using command-line. Got mc, joe, gcc. Instructions are clear and useful. Install script worked well using option "2l". Good job and thanks!

title: Nice
comment: Really nice, exactly what i needed. No chroot, fully integrated. Now i can use vim, ssh, mc, moc, apt-get. Finally the android shell is useful.

title: Setup lacks allot of steps
comment: I am having troubles with the setup because, lack of info.
